intro: Symplocos subandina, commonly known as the Andean wax tree, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Ericaceae family and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and small, clustered flowers. The plant produces berries that are typically red or yellow when mature, containing several seeds. Symplocos subandina thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in forest understories. Its botanical features make it an important species in the ecological dynamics of its native habitat.
